newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Partnership needed even with expanded NATO - Joulwan.
newsitem.headline: Partnership needed even with expanded NATO - Joulwan.

text.p: Supreme Allied Commander in Europe General George Joulwan said on Tuesday that cooperation programmes with non-members must continue no matter what deadline U.S. President Clinton sets for NATO expansion.

"I'm not sure what the political decisions will be, but we will adjust," Joulwan said during a visit to Hungary, which is a member of NATO's Partnership for Peace (PFP) programme and a prime candidate for membership in an expanded NATO.
"No matter what, PFP must continue in developing the way ahead," Joulwan told a news conference.
President Clinton was expected to announce on Tuesday that his target was to bring new members into the western military alliance no later than 1999, which is NATO's 50th anniversary.

The Czech Republic, Poland and Hungary are generally viewed as being first in line to join, although Russia has made clear that Moscow still views NATO's planned eastward expansion as a threat to its own security.
Joulwan also said he was ready for a decision over the postponement of municipal elections in Bosnia, where NATO's IFOR peacekeeping troops maintain order.
"We are prepared to support municipal elections if they're held in November but OSCE (Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe) has the lead, not us," he said.
Joulwan said NATO's land force command for central Europe, including IFOR, will move to Sarajevo from Heidelberg, Germany by the first week of November.
He said the mission would oversee the redeployment of IFOR forces at the end of the IFOR mandate, set for December 20.
He added that the headquarters would be expanded to include non-NATO members.
"The mission will include 25 nationalities, including Hungarian officers," he added.
